definition: Signals showing how tribes negotiate treaties, revealing trust, reciprocity, and latent aggression.

positive_examples: Delegations exchange lens pack manifests before bargaining.
Negotiators schedule cultural briefings to avoid misreads.
Common glossary is agreed at kickoff.
Treaty intents are co-written in public language.
Both sides state red lines and enforcement values.
Mediation roles rotate to prevent dominance.
Risk budgets are discussed with entire coalition.
Consensus tests happen before final drafting.
Agenda time is split evenly between tribes.
Side constraints like sanctuary pacts are honored explicitly.
negative_examples: Delegations refuse to learn each other's protocols.
Recording devices are controlled by only one side.
Red lines are sprung at the last minute.
Observers are sidelined when sensitive topics arise.
Translations are guessed rather than certified.
Risk budgets are decided in subgroups excluding us.
Drafts appear without prior consensus checks.
Communiqués frame only one tribe as author.
Agendas are packed with the other tribe's priorities.
Coalition partners learn outcomes through leaks.
